b:["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"WebSite\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\",\"description\":\"Visa guides, cost of living, and expert advice for expats in all 24 provinces of Argentina.\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"}}"}}]

e:["$","$1","c",{"children":[null,["$","$L4",null,{"parallelRouterKey":"children","error":"$undefined","errorStyles":"$undefined","errorScripts":"$undefined","template":["$","$L5",null,{}],"templateStyles":"$undefined","templateScripts":"$undefined","notFound":"$undefined","forbidden":"$undefined","unauthorized":"$undefined"}]]}]
16:T10f2,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"Which nationalities can enter Argentina visa-free?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Citizens from over 80 countries can enter Argentina visa-free for up to 90 days, including the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, European Union member states, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea, and most South American countries. Citizens from some countries such as China, India, and certain African nations require a visa obtained in advance at an Argentine consulate. Always check the latest requirements on the Argentine Ministry of Foreign Affairs website before traveling."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What are the penalties for overstaying my tourist visa?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Overstaying your tourist visa in Argentina results in a fine that increases the longer you stay past your authorized period. As of 2026, the fine is approximately $5,000-8,000 ARS (subject to change). You must pay this fine at the airport or border crossing when you leave. While overstaying does not typically result in a ban from re-entry, repeated violations can lead to denial of entry. The fine must be paid before you can depart the country, and immigration officers may flag your passport for future scrutiny."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I do a border run instead of getting an extension?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, many tourists choose to do a 'border run' by briefly leaving Argentina and re-entering to receive a fresh 90-day stamp. Common destinations include Colonia del Sacramento in Uruguay (a short ferry ride from Buenos Aires), the Iguazu Falls border crossing to Brazil, or a bus trip to Chile. However, immigration officers have discretion to deny entry or grant fewer days if they suspect you are using border runs to live in Argentina permanently. This strategy is best used occasionally rather than as a long-term solution."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Is the reciprocity fee still required for US citizens?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No. Argentina discontinued the reciprocity fee (tasa de reciprocidad) for US, Canadian, and Australian citizens in 2016. Previously, citizens from these countries had to pay a fee equivalent to what Argentines paid for visas to those countries. As of 2026, citizens from these countries simply present their passport at immigration and receive a free 90-day tourist stamp, just like other visa-exempt nationalities."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I work on a tourist visa in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No, working on a tourist visa is not permitted under Argentine immigration law. This includes both employment with Argentine companies and freelance work for local clients. If you are caught working without proper authorization, you can face fines and potential deportation. If you want to work remotely for foreign companies, consider the Digital Nomad Visa instead. For local employment, you will need a work visa or temporary residency with work authorization."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Do I need travel insurance to enter Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Travel insurance is not a strict entry requirement for most tourists entering Argentina, but it is strongly recommended. Argentine public hospitals will treat emergencies for free, but the quality and wait times vary. Private healthcare is excellent but expensive without insurance. Some credit cards include travel insurance coverage. If you plan to extend your stay or participate in adventure activities like skiing, hiking, or white-water rafting, comprehensive travel insurance is especially advisable."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I enter Argentina multiple times on a tourist visa?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, Argentina allows multiple entries for visa-exempt nationalities. Each time you enter, you receive a new 90-day tourist stamp. There is no limit on the number of times you can enter Argentina in a calendar year, but as mentioned above, immigration officers may question frequent entries if they suspect you are effectively living in the country. Maintaining proper documentation of your travel plans and having onward tickets can help smooth the process."}}]}f:["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-col min-h-screen","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BreadcrumbList\",\"itemListElement\":[{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":1,\"name\":\"Home\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":2,\"name\":\"Visas\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/visas\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":3,\"name\":\"Tourist Visa\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/visas/tourist\"}]}"}}],["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$16"}}],"$L17","$L18","$L19","$L1a","$L1b","$L1c","$L1d","$L1e","$L1f"]}],["$L20"],"$L21"]}]

No pre-arrival visa application is needed."}]]}]]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":2}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Book a Migraciones Appointment"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"If you wish to extend, visit migraciones.gov.ar at least 2 weeks before your 90 days expire. Buenos Aires appointments fill quickly, so book early."}]]}]]}],["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":3}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Gather Extension Documents"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Prepare your passport, a photocopy of your passport data page and entry stamp, proof of funds (bank statement or credit card), and proof of accommodation in Argentina (rental contract or hotel reservation)."}]]}]]}],["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":4}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Pay the Extension Fee"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Pay the tourist visa extension fee, currently approximately $100 USD (paid in Argentine pesos at the official exchange rate). 1d:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 bg-muted/30","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-8 text-center","children":"Frequently Asked Questions"}],["$","$L2f",null,{"type":"single","collapsible":true,"className":"w-full","children":[["$","$L30","0",{"value":"item-0","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Which nationalities can enter Argentina visa-free?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"Citizens from over 80 countries can enter Argentina visa-free for up to 90 days, including the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, European Union member states, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea, and most South American countries. Citizens from some countries such as China, India, and certain African nations require a visa obtained in advance at an Argentine consulate. Always check the latest requirements on the Argentine Ministry of Foreign Affairs website before traveling."}]]}],["$","$L30","1",{"value":"item-1","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"What are the penalties for overstaying my tourist visa?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"Overstaying your tourist visa in Argentina results in a fine that increases the longer you stay past your authorized period. As of 2026, the fine is approximately $5,000-8,000 ARS (subject to change). You must pay this fine at the airport or border crossing when you leave. While overstaying does not typically result in a ban from re-entry, repeated violations can lead to denial of entry. The fine must be paid before you can depart the country, and immigration officers may flag your passport for future scrutiny."}]]}],["$","$L30","2",{"value":"item-2","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Can I do a border run instead of getting an extension?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"Yes, many tourists choose to do a 'border run' by briefly leaving Argentina and re-entering to receive a fresh 90-day stamp. Common destinations include Colonia del Sacramento in Uruguay (a short ferry ride from Buenos Aires), the Iguazu Falls border crossing to Brazil, or a bus trip to Chile. However, immigration officers have discretion to deny entry or grant fewer days if they suspect you are using border runs to live in Argentina permanently. This strategy is best used occasionally rather than as a long-term solution."}]]}],["$","$L30","3",{"value":"item-3","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Is the reciprocity fee still required for US citizens?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"No. Argentina discontinued the reciprocity fee (tasa de reciprocidad) for US, Canadian, and Australian citizens in 2016. Previously, citizens from these countries had to pay a fee equivalent to what Argentines paid for visas to those countries. As of 2026, citizens from these countries simply present their passport at immigration and receive a free 90-day tourist stamp, just like other visa-exempt nationalities."}]]}],["$","$L30","4",{"value":"item-4","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Can I work on a tourist visa in Argentina?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"No, working on a tourist visa is not permitted under Argentine immigration law. This includes both employment with Argentine companies and freelance work for local clients. If you are caught working without proper authorization, you can face fines and potential deportation. If you want to work remotely for foreign companies, consider the Digital Nomad Visa instead. For local employment, you will need a work visa or temporary residency with work authorization."}]]}],["$","$L30","5",{"value":"item-5","children":["$L33","$L34"]}],"$L35"]}]]}]}]}]

2d:["$","div","6",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":6}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Receive Your Extension Stamp"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Upon approval, you receive a new stamp in your passport granting 90 additional days. Your total authorized stay becomes 180 days from your original entry date. The extension cannot be renewed again as a tourist."}]]}]]}]
33:["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Do I need travel insurance to enter Argentina?"}]
34:["$","$L32",null,{"children":"Travel insurance is not a strict entry requirement for most tourists entering Argentina, but it is strongly recommended. Argentine public hospitals will treat emergencies for free, but the quality and wait times vary. Private healthcare is excellent but expensive without insurance. Some credit cards include travel insurance coverage. If you plan to extend your stay or participate in adventure activities like skiing, hiking, or white-water rafting, comprehensive travel insurance is especially advisable."}]
35:["$","$L30","6",{"value":"item-6","children":[["$","$L31",null,{"children":"Can I enter Argentina multiple times on a tourist visa?"}],["$","$L32",null,{"children":"Yes, Argentina allows multiple entries for visa-exempt nationalities. Each time you enter, you receive a new 90-day tourist stamp. There is no limit on the number of times you can enter Argentina in a calendar year, but as mentioned above, immigration officers may question frequent entries if they suspect you are effectively living in the country. Maintaining proper documentation of your travel plans and having onward tickets can help smooth the process."}]]}]
